comments.commentBody: Apparently James Baker III is the dynast who remains in place even as presidents come and go.
Ted Cruz or Marco Rubio would be excellent choices for the Republicans. I seriously believe either one of them could give Hillary a run for her money.
Scott Walker...

Like most voters of both Parties, I'd rather not elect a member of a dynasty to be President.

But if Jeb Bush runs against Hillary Clinton, the dynasty issue is neutralized, and it would easier to support Hillary, although there are other Democrats I prefer. Although Hillary would have easily beat Mitt, she can also easily be elected President over Jeb.

With Romney dropping from the race, the likelihood of Bush getting nominated has increased, which also increases the chance of the Hillary being elected. If Hillary is not nominated, than Jeb's election chances are further decreased, because most Republicans and independents probably also would prefer avoiding a dynasty.

So far, the Republicans have unelectable choices, but perhaps an unexpected Republican candidate can be nominated, who is not reactionary and bigoted, but I can't imagine who that might be - perhaps Olympia Snow.

Ms Snow would neutralize the gender advantage of Ms Clinton, and would take advantage of Hillary being part of a dynasty. Reactionary, bigoted Republican voters might not like that choice and many would not vote, but it would also confound many Democrats whose main support of Clinton would be to elect our first female President.

If Jeb Bush is nominated, and Hillary Clinton is not, then Jeb will lose due to the dynasty issue, and because reactionary Republicans mistakenly think Bush is moderate and bigots don't like the fact he is married to a Latino. But Jeb probably won't be nominated.
Jeb is a MINO ( moderate in name only ), not a RINO. He is pure Republican, right down to his Reaganite views on amnesty.
Jeb can beat madam hillary and that is THE MOST IMPORTANT THING.. Keeping her and her sort of husband out of the WH is very important for the integrity of this country.

There isn't a so called "strong constitutionalist" out there who understands what rot has followed from failure to enforce the constitutional ban on faith based legislation. In fact, they seem to be a large chunk of the rot in question.
You run Jeb, you lose.  No more RINOs.

If you try and force people to have their kids vaccinated, all you'll hear is how their freedoms have been violated, how we live in a police state, how vaccination is part of Obamacare's gestapo medical care and tons of conspiracy theories.

Unfortunately, most Americans know virtually nothing about science and they're quite happy to get their misguided and incorrect information from other idiots on the web. We're becoming more and more like a third world country where we rely less on enlightenment and science and more on religion, superstition and closely held beliefs that have no basis in reality. Why is it that we seemed a lot smarter when far fewer people attended college?

Parents are in a panic about autism and those who have autistic kids feel so guilty that they need somebody or something to blame and it just happens to be vaccines, whether it's the vaccine itself or the preservatives. Until we find out the exact causes of autism, we're going to be in this state of panic. And there are plenty of politicians who just love buying in to that panic.

I'm hoping this current measles situation causes parents who question vaccines to start understanding the importance of getting kids vaccinated. On the other hand, growing up in the 1950s and 60s, many of today's vaccines weren't yet available and I as well as most of my classmates easily survived the measles, chicken pox and German measles. I never got the mumps, although my younger brother did.

Allowing the freedom to exercise ignorantly founded beliefs over scientifically proven threats to public health prioritizes politics over people and undermines one of the greatest accomplishments of modern medicine: eradication of preventable disease.

Schoolchildren deserve better.

We can all thank Dr. Andrew Wakefield for publishing the first paper claiming that autism was caused by vaccines. Even though the article was retracted and scientists have determined that the ONE thing they know that doesn't cause autism is vaccinations, he continues to fill conference halls full of parents who don't know or refuse to believe the science:

http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/21/autisms-unrepentant-guru/

I don't know wether autism cases are really more common nowadays, since the diagnostic criteria changed so drastically. But if they really did increase, might not be the one big change be responsible, namely the steady increase in  the age of parents. Mutations in eggs and sperms occur more frequently  the older the parents are.

"Even when presented with the clearest and strongest data, whether from government or industry, they do not believe it or simply do not trust any institution."

Religion has survived on this premise for thousands of years. When the precious snowflakes of these parents melt forever, the parents will be left with a heavy burden. Sad indeed.

Almost every person over 50 has got the measles as a child, often intentionally to prevent getting measles at an older age when they could be far more serious. For example, pregnant women who get measles can expect harmful complications, but most other people can expect only a month of misery.

The vaccine scare is just one more example of our nation's worthless school system and how it affects stubborn adults. If smoking and guns can be banned in public spaces, then unvacinnated people can also be banned and politicians who do not put the ban in place are as guilty as those promoting smoking and killing children in schools.

I read the article superficially. What I got out of it is, that children of women who were vaccinated against measles lost the antibodies  aquired from their mothers at birth two month earlier. There was no difference with mumps and rubella. Now that would be absolutely no problem, if everybody is vaccinated. The famous herd effect would especially protect these vulnerable infants!

My friend had the measles in the 60s. She was pregnant at the time. Her son was born blind, deaf, and cognitively impaired. She and her husband were completely devastated. That is how a healthy person responds to these serious diseases.
"We all got better"? In 1962 a little boy two doors down from my family died of the measles. I remember it very well.

You also have to factor in the generally healthier lifestyle lived in true Amish communities - fresh, home cooked meals, no alcohol or drugs, lots of outdoor exercise and so forth. All of those things build health immune systems that sadly are lacking in the general public.
As a matter of fact, I recommend, that doctors, who oppose vaccinations, lose their license for endangering the health of  their patients. This is the worst form of malpractice I can think of.
Yes, the MMR vaccine protects against roseola (measles), mumps, and rubella (German measles). I had German measles as a child.
"Three-day measles" = German measles = rubella. MMR vaccine = measles, mumps, rubella.
Unfortunately  the hundred dollars don't go far!
Politics. You can do a google search to find out more about how this came into being and why it has stuck around.

If vaccine is such a magic pill, why does the "National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program" exist?

For those inclined towards scientific data, I would suggest reading this:
http://www.hrsa.gov/vaccinecompensation/statisticsreport.pdf

I think it goes beyond that.
In the USA, we have lived with political, governmental and media fear mongering and hysteria sine 9/11 or maybe it goes back to the first Gulf War,
I think the constant fear, the constant hysteria, the constant attacks on government and all the institutions it touches has created a psychopathology in many otherwise functioning Americans that leads to things like this mass hysteria over vaccinations.
Anyone who cites Mercola as a scientific source has no credibility.

I've met some of these people. Though they'd be loathe to say it out loud, their attidue is basically "we're nice, clean people who live in a nice, clean house in a nice, clean neighborhood and we don't have to worry about dirty, icky diseases that dirty, icky people get in their dirty, icky homes in dirty, icky neighborhoods." Science has nothing to do with it. They can't be bothered to inconvenience themselves and their perfect offspring. If it kills someone else, that is not their problem. When their own kids start to get measles, however, their tune will change real fast. And one of the perfect parents comes down sick, all hell will be be loosed. That, my friends, will be a different story.

I got chicken pox for the first time when I was 30 years old. Yes, it was hell, and painful and miserable for a long time. But I survived. Would I recommend chicken pox vaccine? No. Its not a deadly disease.

Since the the efficacy of antibiotics and antivirals is steadily declining, even a vaccine, that is not more than 50% effective, will create a good enough herd effect, if all people are vaccinated, who are not immunocompromised.
By the way, nobody is talking of the side effects of antibiotics and especially antivirals.

Find out what shingles are, just for starters.

Then, look up a) how many kids died from measles the year you were seven, and b) how many kids died from polio and all the rest.

Then, pack your bags, drive to every family whose kid dies from measles this year or is permanently crippled, and don't forget to include any and all pregnant women exposed with an 84% chance of infection and a 54% chance that their unborn will be badly damaged.

Knock on the door, and when they answr, read your post aloud. i'm sure we all look forward to hearing about how that goes for you.
There was a show about this today on Science Friday from PRI on NPR.  If I understood it right, they said there was less aluminum in it than from using an aluminum pan to cook dinner.

I think the CDC is an excellent organization but you folks are forgetting their apologies for not having the right procedures spelled out to begin with.  Does anyone doubt that some luck was involved here?
Most side effects from modern vaccine are temporary, but appear in the statistics. Severe and permanent damage is very rare.
